title: Young Hunter Hearing Call to Arms
provenance_text:
Marsden Hartley [1877-1943], Maine; Paul Rosenberg & Co., New York, NY, probably by 1942 [1]; Marsden Hartley estate, September 1943 until December 1943 [2]; purchased by Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, January 1944 [3].

Notes:
[1] The Rosenberg Gallery began to represent Hartley in 1942. The painting (as "The Hunter") was exhibited there in 1942. See "American Paintings and Sculpture to 1945 in the Carnegie Museum of Art," page 232, under Exhibitions.
[2]. Following the artist's death in September 1943, the Rosenberg Gallery was acting as representative of his estate. See copies of correspondence between John O'Connor, Jr. and Paul Rosenberg in curatorial file.
[3]. The painting was no. 164 (illustrated, plate 66) in the exhibition "Painting in the United States" held at Carnegie Institute, October-December, 1943. The museum purchased the painting shortly after the exhibition closed via Paul Rosenberg & Co. (invoice dated December 15, 1943, with payment acknowledged on December 30, 1943.) The painting was accessioned on January 14, 1944.
